author: namngrg
content:
Thanks for this! This was very helpful

https://github.com/gballet/go-verkle/blob/dbd9bfcff2b0b5a108cf8f7ecbc0b51080bfeacf/tree_test.go#L261 here why is it **other** Cn ? Shouldnt it be same as the suffix is the only difference, like key1p? Or am I misunderstanding something üòÖ

author: jsign
content:
Remember that in LeafNodes you have C1 and C2, since the 256 values are split in two groups. The elements from [0, 127] live in C1 and [128, 255] live in C2. The `80` suffix (remember is hex) is 129, so it leaves in C2 and not in C1 like the other two mentioend values. 
I think you were thinking if they live in the same "leaf commitment", which the answer is yes. But that code is referencing the C1 and C2 at the leaf node level.
lmk if makes sense now

author: namngrg
content:
Another small question - In this diagram, we inserted v192, due to which v127 came down to C(2,0). So if we now delete v192 will v127 go back to its original place or stay there itself? 

Also, in the left diagram why is the arrow shown from C(0,4), shouldnt it be from C(0,0) . Also written below the diagram "The initial node is untouched, and C¬≤‚ÇÄ has the same value as C‚Å∞‚ÇÄ before the insertion."

author: jsign
content:
> So if we now delete v192 will v127 go back to its original place or stay there itself? 
In theory, yes. But remember that no values get deleted from the VKT. There's a part in the article that mentions that in bold IIRC; so you shouldn't be thinking much about that.

>  in the left diagram why is the arrow shown from C(0,4), shouldnt it be from C(0,0)
Yes.. I remember now this was something that I also thought was a mistake when I first read the article. I don't remember if was planned to be fixed...
In any case, I agree that that arrow origin should be C(0, 0).

author: namngrg
content:
Got it! Actually I saw the **Delete** function and some tests on it in the Go implementation and since I am working on the Nim implementation I thought to add it too. Any suggestions?
Thanks!

author: jsign
content: I checked with Guillaume. The reason that is there is comes from some old-ish "bulk method" migration strategy code need. It isn't longer needed.
